When I was 19 or 20, I broke up with a man who was super handsome, responsible, earned good money and would earn more, took care of me when I was sick, great lover, told me he loved me. I ended it because women were always chasing and flirting with him. He barely paid them any attention but I was afraid he would and that he would fall in love with another woman and leave me. So I married a man who I met before him who was none of those things. Had 2 children with him and got divorced. All because I didn’t have enough confidence in MYSELF and didn’t feel deserving of the good man who looked too good to be true. He was heartbroken when we were over. A woman who’d been after him the whole time we were together finally got his attention. They married and divorced. She was nothing like me. He then married a woman he did love and lived happily with her until he died a few years ago. I never remarried. I’m 73 now.

regretList.regret: I started my career in my 20's during the late 1980's early 1990's.   Like so many women of my time I was subject to constant sexual harassment and abuse in the work place.  I was not on my own in experiencing this behaviour which was rife at the time.  Speaking out was impossible as usually the person most harmed was the woman raising the complaint and risking a mark on her career that would make her unemployable to others.  This abuse had a terrible and long term impact on my personal life and relationships and it was about 20 years before I could put the psychological damage caused behind me.  Looking back on that time I regret not finding a way to fight back strategically.  Tribunals and court cases might not have been an option but I could have found a way not to be a victim to such behaviour, I regret not having the cognitive strength back then to deal with situations differently.

Once upon a time I was a brand new financial advisor. Our company had a veteran advisor retire, or so I thought, but that was not the whole story. The backstory, which I found out later, is that he was a lazy advisor who was forced out because he was not being proactive with his clients. 

Every day I came to work early, stayed late, and prospected in ways that other new advisors were not willing to do. For example one time I went into a strip club with my business cards and on the back of them I wrote things like "I bet you make a lot of money, are you making smart decisions about your financial future? Give me a call." on the back of the card. I am sure you can guess how many calls I received.

When this advisor left I began calling his clients and having them come in to meet me. I saw they were in investments that might not have been appropriate, lack of diversification, higher ongoing costs, etc.

In the early 2000's I committed financial infidelity. I hid credit card debt from my husband so I could buy things to make myself look more successful than I was. Then I lost my job and we had to downsize our house because we had no emergency savings (because of me.) I started a new career moving from corporate finance (something I hated but did for 25 years because I loved the money and prestige.) to marketing. That was my first degree and something I should have stuck with. I was depressed and filled with shame. Started taking Xanax and proceeded to get TWO DUIs. One was dismissed but the second one stuck. My husband and I separated for 6 weeks in 2017. We have reunited, and I am finally making a good living doing what I ENJOY. My true gifting. I can see God's hand on me through this process. I know I am forgiven by the grace of God and my husband says he is proud of me. Yet I still cannot believe what I was capable of. And Satan is a crafty bastard. Thanks for listening!

When I was a college freshman, our professor asked the class if anyone would volunteer to take notes on non-carbon paper that would produce a duplicate set of notes for a physically disabled student in the class. I promptly avoided eye contact with the professor until another student volunteered.

I’ve thought about this decision from time to time and what motivated it. My own selfishness made me think first of the “hardship” of making such a commitment: I would have to attend every class, be on time, take good notes, and write legibly.

That was my hardship. I didn’t consider the difficulties my classmate faced—just to get to class.

I went to an elite UK university, won a scholarship while there and looked set to go on to an academic career. That was my dream. But on the first day of finals I totally lost my nerve, panicked, missed the exams and went AWOL for a couple of days (regret 1). After tracking me down, my parents persuaded me to go back and complete the rest of my exams, which, out of guilt I did and so ended up with a mediocre degree (regret 2) - quite an achievement in the circumstances, I guess, but devastating for an incurable perfectionist like me. If only I'd either had the courage to turn up for the exams on day one and taken my chances or stuck to my decision to drop out at the 11th hour and saved myself further humiliation. But I did neither. I took the coward's path - twice in succession. They say you regret the things you didn't do more than those you did. But my 'sin' was both of commission and omission. After 40yrs, it's a double wound that has never healed. Time, you are not a great healer!

Unfortunately I was always crazy busy with teenage stuff and then went away to college, graduated, married and soon thereafter my father died.  FYI: I've always made my 'big regret' known to my own kids & grandkids. And they would lovingly humor me (with an occasional rolling-of-the-eyes) by listening to my stories.  Years ago, for a Christmas present, my teenage son gifted me a blank notebook and requested that I write stories in it that pop into my head when he wasn't there to listen to them ... and which I might forget to tell him.  Fast forward to now that he has own two children, he tells them of my "big regret".  Of course there's the occasional eye-roll  ... but they lovingly listen as he launches into his stories.
